### Example: Parallel Rays Focusing at the Focal Point

A fundamental property of lenses is that a bundle of parallel rays will be focused to a single point at exactly the focal distance after the lens. We can demonstrate this mathematically using matrix optics.

Consider a system with:
- A lens with focal length $f$
- Free space of distance $d$ after the lens
- A parallel bundle of rays (all with angle $\theta = 0$) entering the lens at different heights $y$

For such a system, the combined matrix is:

$$
\mathbf{M}_{system} = \mathbf{M}_{free} \times \mathbf{M}_{lens} = 
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
1 & d \\
0 & 1
\end{array}\right] \times
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
-\frac{1}{f} & 1
\end{array}\right] =
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
1-\frac{d}{f} & d \\
-\frac{1}{f} & 1
\end{array}\right]
$$

When parallel rays enter the system, each ray has parameters $(y, 0)$ where $y$ is the height and the angle is zero.

Applying the system matrix:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{c}
y_{final} \\
\theta_{final}
\end{array}\right] = 
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
1-\frac{d}{f} & d \\
-\frac{1}{f} & 1
\end{array}\right] \times
\left[\begin{array}{c}
y \\
0
\end{array}\right] =
\left[\begin{array}{c}
y \left(1-\frac{d}{f}\right) \\
-\frac{y}{f}
\end{array}\right]
$$

For all rays to converge to a single point (forming a sharp image), the final position $y_{final}$ must be independent of the initial height $y$. This can only happen when the coefficient $\left(1-\frac{d}{f}\right) = 0$, which gives us $d = f$.

Therefore, the sharp image forms at exactly the focal distance $f$ after the lens. At this point, all rays converge to $y_{final} = 0$, meaning they intersect the optical axis.
